captions.text:
i've been a blacksmith armor for over
thirty years.

I've created weapons for over two
hundred feature films.
This is Man at Arms.
I made a full scale pattern for Skyrim's Orc Axe by making a photocopy.
Blowing it up to sixty inches overall length.
I'm gonna have to put in extra effort on this to make the sword look like it
was built by an Orc.
The Orc Axe has a 5160 hardened steel rough forged cutting edge.

This is the type of steel they use in mac truck
leaf springs.

After I cut out the rough profileon the band
saw, I'm hammering in the bevels.
I have to use the forge to heat the metal so that it'll be able to be manipulated.
It's a time consuming process. It takes as long as it takes to get it right.
Using the belt grinder really refines the shape that
I have initially established cutting out with the band saw. Even though it's an Orc weapon,
it's supposed to be crude. Give it kind of a refined crudeness.

I put it in the heat treating furnace, brought it
up to fifteen hundred fifty degrees.

Brought it out put it into the quench take with
oil.

I had a little bit of a problem with
this blade. It barely was able to be
immersed into my quench tank.
I was able to finagle my hardening oil tank just to make it fit.
Then we put it back into the heat treating oven at five hundred seventy five

degrees for about four hours to
temper it.
For the half dome of the Skyrim Orc Axe,
I'm using a piece of red oak red oak that's tree inches square. Then cut it out on the band saw.
Then took it to the belt grinder.
Ground away all the wood in a rough-hewn type of appearance.
If this was made by an Orc craftsman

he wouldn't have access to a belt grinder
he would've done everything with an axe.
So I'm making it look like everything was axe cuts.
I'm using the knuckle from a buffalo femur for the bottom of the axe handle.
I have a storage container just filled with the weirdest stuff.
People come in and going
'Hey, we're looking for a bunch of wildebeest horns,'
or in this case, buffalo femurs.
The apoxy glue that I mix together is an industrial adhesive.
The steel will rust away the bronze will corrode and will eventually disappear. The wood will

be eaten by termites but that apoxy glue
will be there for hundreds of years.
I took a strip of leather that I cut into a spiral leaving some torn
edges on the leather then barged some of that over
the shaft of the axe handle in a criss-cross pattern.

Right now i'm just patterning out the
pocket that will hold the blade
together with rivets.
I have a sheet of eighty thousand silicon bronze that my assistant Brian
beat the hell out on the anvil
just to give it some Orcish texture.
My initial idea was to make the wrap going around the shaft not out of bronze but out of steel.
I decided to go with bronze to give it a nice two-tone effect.
I'm making another two collars and a spike cover that will go over the end of the wooden shaft.
That will attach to the piece of silicon bronze that holds the steel blade.
It's actually more difficult to make an older, cruder looking weapon

because i have to put in all of
the profiles details and everything
and intentionally age it and distress it.
This axe came out really Orcish, if that's a word.
The hammered bronze, the rough hammered steel,
the rough-hewn oak shaft, and the raw pieces of leather,
and the buffalo knee-joint on the bottom of it.
Thanks for watching Man at Arms. Be sure to subscribe.

Tell me in the comments what weapon you'd
like to see next.
